channel.title: Stories from thehustle.co - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best thehustle.co stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Everyone Is Baking — And Entrepreneurs Are Rising Up To Meet The Demand
item.description: A look behind the numbers driving the latest quarantine craze and the small businesses that are filling a gap in the market.

item.title: How Small Business Owners Survived The Great Recession
item.description: As COVID-19 rattles small businesses around the country, inspiration can be drawn from the stories of those who survived the last financial crisis.

item.title: Meet The COVID-19 College Graduates
item.description: Left out of the stimulus bill, Class of 2020 college grads are stumbling into a job market that isn't ready for them.

item.title: The End-Of-The-world Business Is Booming
item.description: "Coronavirus is just the spark," says one doomsday prep supplier. "What's really driving sales is the fear of what's to come."

item.title: Amid A Pandemic, Uber Drivers Choose Between Health And Livelihood
item.description: As America holes up inside, thousands of full-time rideshare drivers are still out on the streets trying to carve out a living.

item.title: The Exploitative Economics Of Cruise Ships
item.description: In the wake of coronavirus and tanking stocks, cruise companies have sought assistance from the US government. But for decades, the industry has done everything in its power to avoid paying into the system.

item.title: The Economics Of Cruise Ships
item.description: In the wake of coronavirus and tanking stocks, cruise companies have sought assistance from the US government. But for decades, the industry has done everything in its power to avoid paying into the system.

item.title: Inside The Wild World Of Government Auctions
item.description: Public agencies sell fire trucks, Black Hawk helicopters, and wedding gowns. Who is actually buying them?

item.title: How Mount Everest Became A Multimillion-Dollar Business
item.description: Growing crowds have turned the world's tallest mountain into a valuable commercial asset. But where's all the money going?

item.title: Digging Into The Weird Economics Of Pawn Shops
item.description: We were big fans of Zachary Crockett's deep dive into the economics of all-you-can eat buffets, and his look at the unpredictable way pawn shops work is similarly great. I've never personally pawned something, but reading the piece, I was almost tempted to go price-comparing at local shops. (But only almost.)

item.title: The Unpredictable Economics Of Pawn Shops
item.description: Take the same item to four different pawn shops and you might get offers that vary by hundreds of dollars. Here's why.

item.title: One Man's Quest To Bring The DeLorean Back To Life
item.description: In a workshop in Humble, Texas, Stephen Wynne is attempting to revive one of history's most beloved and beleaguered cars.

item.title: A Serious Investigation Of How To 'Out-Eat' An All-You-Can-Eat Buffet
item.description: I'm sure we've all gone to buffets before and wondered, as we're stuffing our faces full of food, how this all-you-can-eat model is sustainable for restaurants. The article helps unlock some of the tricks buffet restaurants deploy to keep us from out-eating them. It also, interestingly, wsheds light on why buffets aren't nearly as popular as they once were.

item.title: The Tricky Economics Of All-You-Can-Eat Buffets
item.description: Is it possible to out-eat the price you pay for a buffet? How do these places make money? We looked at the dollars and cents behind the meat and potatoes.

item.title: Why It Only Costs $10k To 'Own' A Chick-Fil-A Franchise
item.description: The chicken chain is known for having the lowest entry cost of any major fast-food franchise — but there's a catch.
item.kicker: AND YOU DON'T HAVE TO WORK SUNDAYS!

item.title: Can A Corporation 'Own' A Color?
item.description: A handful of companies have pushed the boundaries of intellectual property law by laying claim to individual colors. But is it really possible to "own" a color?

item.title: The Economics Of Unused Gift Cards
item.description: Every year, Americans spend billions of dollars on gift cards. But what happens to the money when the cards aren't redeemed?

item.title: How Tipsy Elves Built A $125m Ugly Christmas Sweater Empire
item.description: Eight years ago, a dentist and a lawyer quit their high-paying jobs to make sweaters.

item.title: Can The American Casket Monopoly Be Disrupted?
item.description: Today, two companies control 82% of all casket sales in the United States. But can a new crop of more affordable and sustainable options shake things up?

item.title: The Man Who Made The 'Worst' Video Game In History
item.description: Howard Scott Warshaw's video game was blamed for single-handedly sinking a multibillion-dollar market. But the true story is more complicated.

item.title: How I Got Sucked Into Cryptocurrency And Made $13 Million
item.description: This is the first-person account of Dan Conway, an ex-middle manager in corporate America who made a fortune betting his life savings on cryptocurrency.

item.title: How Pizza Hut Lost Its Edge
item.description: Once an innovation powerhouse, with creations like 'Stuffed Crust' and 'BigFoot,' Pizza Hut has been forced to shift focus from food to technology.

item.title: How One Man Went From A Life Prison Sentence To A $100K+ Engineering Job
item.description: In 1996, Zachary Moore committed a murder. Today, he's a computer engineer at a Silicon Valley tech firm. Here's how he got there.

item.title: SmileDirectClub Officially Takes The (Dental) Crown As The Worst IPO Of 2019
item.description: In a year of lackluster IPOs, SmileDirectClub takes the cake as the worst after losing 60% of its value in a month due to new regulation.

item.title: The Local News Celebrity Who Rigged The State Lottery
item.description: In 1980, a church leader and trusted newsman exploited flaws in the Pennsylvania state lottery — and nearly got away with it.

item.title: How One Woman Build A Business Out Of Retailers' Throwaway Mannequins
item.description: When big retail chains want to get rid of their mannequins, they call Judi Townsend, America's premier "mannequin broker."

item.title: The Man Who Built His Own Lamborghini
item.description: When Mike Vetter's dream of owning a Lamborghini didn't come to fruition, he built one himself. Now he earns a living making his own supercars.
item.kicker: DIY TO DOING IT FOR EVERYONE

item.title: Amazon Released Shoes Under A Private Label That Look Pretty Much The Same As Allbirds
item.description: Amazon is infamous for copying hot product designs and selling cheaper versions under its own private labels.
item.kicker: AIN'T NOTHING LIKE THE REAL THING

item.title: Is The Era Of The $100 Graphing Calculator Coming To An End?
item.description: Texas Instruments has enjoyed a near monopoly on graphing calculators for nearly three decades. But new technology may be threatening the company's empire.
item.kicker: OUT WITH THE OLD, IN WITH THE NEW

item.title: The Epic, Decades-Long Battle Between Ford And A Small-Time Inventor
item.description: 50 years ago, Ford stole a patented design for a new type of windshield wiper. But they picked the wrong inventor the screw with.

item.title: Why Nobody Ever Wins The Car Giveaway At The Mall
The Worst Sales Promotion In History
item.description: In 1992, an electronics company offered two free international flights with any £100 purchase. The rest, well… sucked.
item.kicker: THINGS NOT TAUGHT IN BIZ SCHOOL

item.title: How A Robotic Singing Fish Made $100m In One Year
item.description: In a world of few hits and constant misses, how did a singing fish mounted on a plaque end up being one of the most iconic gag gifts in history?

item.title: Why Is Airport Food So Expensive?
item.description: The reasons you pay a 200% markup on a water bottle are more complex than you might think.
item.kicker: THAT NOT SO SWEET TRANSIT PREMIUM

item.title: How Much Money Can You Make On Amazon Mechanical Turk?
item.description: Mechanical Turk offers workers the freedom to complete menial tasks for small sums of cash. But is the platform really a viable part-time hustle?

item.title: The 70-Year-Old Retiree Who Became America's Worst Counterfeiter
item.description: How a 73-year-old junk collector produced thousands of the ugliest counterfeit $1 bills ever made — and eluded federal agents for more than a decade.

item.title: The Restaurant Owner Who Asked For 1-Star Yelp Reviews
item.description: How one small business owner flipped the online review ecosystem on its head.

item.title: The $500 Million Smiley Face Business
item.description: Nearly 50 years ago, one man "invented" the modern smiley face. Then, another man halfway across the world made it into a multimillion-dollar cash cow.

item.title: Shark Tank Deep Dive: A Data Analysis Of All 10 Seasons
item.description: What does the average Shark Tank deal look like? It depends on what you're pitching and who you are.

item.title: The Professor Who Beat The Roulette Table
item.description: How a renowned researcher beat the odds, stumped casino owners around the world and walked away with a fortune.

item.title: The Yodeler Who Sued Yahoo
item.description: Twenty years ago, Yahoo decided to roll out a new national advertising campaign. Unfortunately, it didn't reveal this plan to its star yodeler.

item.title: 5-Star Phonies: Inside The Fake Amazon Review Complex
item.description: I spent two weeks in the underbelly of Amazon's fake review economy and emerged questioning our collective trust in the stars.

item.title: The Wild World Of Trust Funds For Pets
item.description: A small but growing number of Americans are leaving inheritances to their pets. How is Fluffy using the money?

item.title: Drunk Shopping Is A $45 Billion Industry. Here's What People Are Buying
item.description: What percentage of alcohol-consuming Americans shop drunk? How much do they spend? What do they buy? We ran a survey to find out.
item.kicker: CLOTHING AND SHOES ARE TOP CHOICE

item.title: I Took A Cannabis DNA Test And Learned More Than I Bargained For
item.description: Direct-to-consumer DNA tests now claim to match you with everything from the right wines to the best strains of weed. But is science really there yet?

item.title: The entrepreneurs who are selling bottled air to China
item.description: A growing number of entrepreneurs are capitalizing on China's air pollution crisis by selling bottled air. But who is it actually helping?

item.title: The $229 Air Purifier That Brought Down The Sharper Image
item.description: How one man built The Sharper Image into the world's wackiest gadget store — and how a spat over an air purifier toppled it.

item.title: Inside Wayback Machine, The Internet's Time Capsule
item.description: The Internet Archive is backing up vast swaths of the web — and grappling with ethical, political and legal questions along the way.
item.kicker: THEY KNOW WHAT YOU POSTED LAST SUMMER

item.title: How the "King of Fake News" built his empire
item.description: Fake news afforded a better life for Jestin Coler and his family, but it came with a high price: his dignity.
item.kicker: FAKE IT SO YOU CAN MAKE IT
